pgTitle: List of places of worship in Berlin

headers.text: Erected (E:) / adapted (A:) / destroyed (D:) / newly built (N:) / recon- structed (R:) in
reli- gion or deno- mina- tion

rows.text: Wilmersdorfer Moschee (i.e. Wilmersdorf Mosque), formerly Berliner Moschee (i.e. Berlin Mosque)
no namesake Wattstraße, congregation now merged with Wedding Baptists
no namesake Boddinstraße (destroyed chapel, front bldg. see photo), Hertzbergstraße (new chapel)
Baptistenkapelle Berlin (i.e. Berlin Baptist Chapel, since it was first and thus at the beginning the only one)
no namesake Schmidstraße 17, congregation moved to Tempelhofer Damm 133–137
no namesake Rothenburgstraße, replacing the ruin on Klingsorstraße 8
no namesake Böhmische Straße / Hertzbergstraße (replacing the destroyed chapel on Boddinstr.)
Dorfkirche Rixdorf (i.e. Rixdorf Village Church) before 1887
E: early 15 th c. D: 1639 R: 1640s
Bethaus der Evangeliums-Christengemeinde Wartenberg (i.e. Prayer House of the Gospel-Christian Congregation Wartenberg)
E: 2 nd half of 13 th c.
Dorfkirche Rosenfelde (i.e. Rosenfelde Village Church) before 1699
E: 1 st half of 13 th c.
E: 2 nd half of 13 th c. D: 1945 R: 1953–1956
E: 2 nd half of 13 th c. A: 1691 D: 20 Apr. 1945
buried in oblivion Breite Straße / Kirchstraße
also St. Immanuelkirche (i.e. St. Immanuel Church) since 1993
Dorfkirche Alt-Tegel (i.e. Old Tegel Village Church)
buried in oblivion Falkenberger Chaussee, 1 st building in Dorfstraße (Wartenberg)
Dorfkirche Dalldorf (i.e. Dalldorf Village Church) before 1905, Sankt Anna-Selbdritt-Kirche (i.e. St. Anna Selbdritt Church) before Reformation
MACHmit! Museum für Kinder (i.e. TAKEpart! Museum for children)

Schlosskapelle (i.e. Palace Chapel); Stiftskirche Unserer Lieben Frauen, des heiligen Kreuzes, St. Petri und Pauli, St. Erasmi und St. Nicolai (i.e. Collegiate Church of Our Lady, the Holy Cross, Ss. Peter and Paul, Erasmus and Nicholas) between 1465 and 1536
Annenkirche (i.e. Anna Church) in analogy to the street name
Französischer Dom (i.e. French Cathedral), Temple de la Friedrichstadt (fr; i.e. Protestant church of Friedrichstadt), Französische Kirche (i.e. French Church)
Franciscan Cloister backyard between Klosterstraße / Großer Jüdenhof, profaned in 1923
Dorfkirche Nieder- schönhausen (i.e. Nieder- schönhausen Village Church)
formerly Friedenskirche (i.e. Peace Church) as Lutheran church until when?
Alte Garnisonskirche (i.e. Old Garrison Church) after 1897
Gemeindehaus Mahlsdorf-Süd (i.e. Mahlsdorf South Community Home)
Gemeindezentrum Grünes Dreieck (i.e. Congregation Centre Green Triangle)
E: 2 nd half of the 13 th c.
Hacı Bayram Camii (i.e. Haci Bayram Mosque)
Neue Johanniskirche (i.e. New John’s Church) till 1907
Herz -Jesu-Kapelle (i.e. Sacred Heart of Jesus Chapel)
St. Izozoel Gemeinde (i.e. Mor Izozoel Congregation)
Imam Cafer Sadik Camii (i.e. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq Mosque)
E: 2 nd half of 13 th c.
Gemeindezentrum Johann Sebastian Bach (i.e. Johann Sebastian Bach Community Centre) before 1980
Gedächtniskirche (i.e. Memorial Church) Hohler Zahn (i.e. hollow tooth) as nickname for the ruined old tower
Hospital pertaining on the hospital campus

Versöhnungskapelle (i.e. Reconciliation Chapel), Versöhnungskirche (i.e. Reconciliation Church) till 1985, church stood in the cleared East German border zone (like Sankt-Franziskus-Kirche, West Staaken), the church was demolished by the end of 1985 following a command by the GDR government
Hospital pertaining on the hospital campus
Bethaniakapelle (i.e. Bethany Chapel) after the Baptist Bethania Congregation using the chapel between 1899 and 1943
Chadidscha-Moschee, Masjid Khadija (i.e. both Khadija Mosque)
Kraftwerk Gottes (i.e. Powerhouse of God), nickname
Hohenzollernplatz square Hohenzollerndamm / Nassauische Straße / Nikolsburger Straße
Neue Garnisonskirche (i.e. New Garrison Church) for Protestant soldiers
Kirche Zu den heiligen Märtyrern von Afrika (i.e. Church of the Holy Martyrs of Africa) before 2008
Sankt -Raphaelsstift (i.e. St. Raphael's Foundation), till 1963 chapel of that foundation
Dorfkirche Pankow (i.e. Pankow Village Church), Alte Pfarrkirche (i.e. old parish church)
E: 1 st half of 15 th c. A: 1858–1859
no namesake Isarstraße 8; a Vereinssynagoge (i.e. synagogue of the private association Jüdische Brüder-Gemeinde Neukölln), after Nazism past on to Jehovah's Witnesses
Synagoge Prinzenallee (i.e. Prinzenallee Synagogue), a Vereinssynagoge (i.e. synagogue of the private association Ahavas Achim אהבת אחים) between 1910 and 1938, then closed after vandalisation
no namesake Prinzenallee 87, profaned in the 1970s
Kirche Alt-Lietzow (i.e. Old Lietzow Church) Dorfkirche Lietzow (i.e. Lietzow Village Church)
Parochialkirche (i.e. Parochial Church) as opposed to the palace chapel till 1826
Sebastiankirche (i.e. Sebastian Church), Luisenstadtkirche (i.e. Luisenstadt Church)
Nethe, Sebastian, city councillor and presbyter Sebastianstraße / Alte Jakobstraße, memorial
Protection of the Mother of God
Dorfkirche Steglitz (i.e. Steglitz Village Church) before 1912
no namesake Nordhausener Straße / Wernigeroder Straße
no namesake Zu den sieben Raben
no namesake Wönnichstraße / Münsterlandplatz, first building in Normannenstraße
no namesake Perleberger Straße 43, the church was profaned and is housing the Tajik Embassy since 2008
Deutscher Dom (i.e. German Cathedral), Deutsche Kirche (i.e. German Church)
Neu-Westend a neighbourhood in Westend Eichenallee

Berliner Dom (i.e. Berlin Cathedral / Collegiate Church) since 1608; Stiftskirche Unserer Lieben Frauen, des heiligen Kreuzes, St. Petri und Pauli, St. Erasmi und St. Nicolai (i.e. Collegiate Church of Our Lady, the Holy Cross, Ss. Peter and Paul, Erasmus and Nicholas) between 1465 and 1536
E: 1 st half of 2 nd c. before the era A: 1897–1901 A: 1930 A: 1939–1941 R: 1959
Radeland (i.e. cleared forest land) Schwanter Weg 3 / Radelandstraße 78
Englische Kirche zu St. Georg (i.e. English Church of St. George)

City-Kirche Berlin International (i.e. Berlin International City Church) between 2005 and 2011; before a Catholic parish; the archdiocese leased the building for 99 years to an art gallery, to be opened in 2013
St. Canissen as of 1957, St.-Canisius-Kapelle (i.e. St. Canisius Chapel) as of 1924
Katholische Kirche (i.e. Catholic Church), Hedwigskirche (i.e. Hedwig's Church) until 1930
Johanneskirche (i.e. John Church) which moved into a new building in 1936
Neue katholische Garnisonskirche (i.e. New Catholic Garrison Church)
Maternitas Beatae Maria Virginis (i.e. Motherhood of the Blessed Virgin Mary)
E: by 1210 N: before 1369 D: 1944 tower R: 1946–1949

Stiftskirche Unserer Lieben Frauen, des heiligen Kreuzes, St. Petri und Pauli, St. Erasmi und St. Nicolai (i.e. Collegiate Church of Our Lady, the Holy Cross, Ss. Peter and Paul, Erasmus and Nicholas) between 1536 and 1608; Berliner Dom (i.e. Berlin Collegiate / Cathedral Church) since 1608
Şehitlik -Friedhof (i.e. the Ottoman diplomats and military cemetery) Columbiadamm
Spandauische Kirche (i.e. Spandau bound Church) till the 1740s
no namesake Tucholskystraße (formerly Artilleriestr.), untouched by the pogrom, forcedly closed in 1939
no namesake Behaimstraße 11; a Vereinssynagoge (i.e. synagogue of a private association) until 1937, then JGB
no namesake Fasanenstraße, only small remnants are inbuilt in the new Jewish community centre
Synagoge Kottbusser Ufer (i.e. Kottbusser Ufer Synagogue)
no namesake Großer Jüdenhof, first synagogue of Berlin
E: 2 nd half of 13 th c. D: 1510
no namesake Heidereutergasse 4, first synagogue after 1672, forcedly closed in Nov. 1942
no namesake Herbartstraße Home for the Elderly
no namesake about Jacobystraße (course of Kaiserstr. removed)
no namesake Freiheit 8; Köpenick Jewish congregation merged into JGB in 1933
no namesake Lessingstraße 19 (renumbered as 6) / Flensburger Straße 14; a Vereinssynagoge (i.e. synagogue of the private association Synagogenverein Moabit und Hansabezirk)
no namesake Lützowstraße, forcedly closed after Pessach 1940
Synagoge im Baruch Auerbachschen Waisenhaus (i.e. Synagogue within the Baruch Auerbachian Orphanage)
no namesake Schönhauser Allee 162; a Vereinssynagoge (i.e. synagogue of a private association), absorbed by the JGB until 1939, the orphanage was forcedly closed in 1942, the orphans deported
Synagoge des Westens (i.e. Synagogue of the West), a Vereinssynagoge (i.e. synagogue of the private association Religionsverein Westen) until 1937, then JGB
Vereinssynagoge (i.e. synagogue of a private association), acquired by the Jewish Community of Berlin in 1919
Tempel or Synagoge Johannisstraße (i.e. Johannisstraße Temple or Synagogue)
no namesake Johannisstraße 16, a Reform temple until 1938, mended to serve the congregants of the New Synagogue after its forced closure in Apr. 1940; forcedly closed in Apr. 1942
no namesake Levetzowstraße; the little damaged synagogue was abused as collection point for deportees
Dorfkirche Hohen- schönhausen (i.e. Hohen- schönhausen Village Church)
Ömer İbnu’l Hattâb Camii (i.e. Umar ibn al-Khattab Mosque)
All Saints Church, Synagoge Sukkat Schalom (i.e. Sukkat Shalom Synagogue), respectively
E: early 2 nd millennium before the era A: 1930 A: 1939–1941 R: 1959
